_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Pikes Fertilizer is an agricultural retail fertilizer and chemical company that primarily sells anhydrous ammonia to area producers for crop  enhancement.

                                                                                                                                                                                          This site is our main office and has 17 nurse tanks with a total capacity of 74,000 pounds whan all tanks are full. The tanks are stored in this area due to the problem with vandalism and meth dealers. The Kansas Department of Agriculture inspects our plant each year and we comply with their request for facility if necessary.

                                                                                                                                                                                          The worst case scenario for our facility would have a toxic gas release of one tank 1,000 lbs with a distance to endpoint of .42 miles and has the potential to affect approximately 726 residents.

                                                                                                                                                                                          The employees who work in the ammonia plant are trained in safety information, hazards, operating procedures, and most importantly the maintenance pratices of our anhydrous ammonia plant.  Employees always wear safety goggles and use appropriate gloves when dealing with nurse tanks.  Clean safety water is always present during ammonia operations.  We inspet our facility on a regular basis and make improvements when necessary.

                                                                                                                                                                                          The excellent training and operation record of our company allows us to report that no injury accidents or property damage has occurred at this

storage facility within the last 5 years.  

                                                                                                                                                                                          The emergency action plans have been shared and discussed with our local rural fire department and they have agreed to assist us in the event of an emergency or accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.
